splitPanel.preferencesPositionDescription: Choose the default split panel position for the service.

modal.description: The application has encountered an unknown error and it is now in an inconsistent state. If you think that this is an error on our side, please help us improve by sending an error report on our <1>GitHub issues page</1>. Close this dialog to go back to the home page.

noMatch.title: Page not found
noMatch.description: You might have typed the address incorrectly or you might have used an outdated link. Check the link and try again.

default.title: $t(global.projectName)
default.description: Create an HPC cluster in AWS using $t(global.projectName). This UI uses the AWS ParallelCluster API to create, edit, and delete clusters, as well as to access and view logs, and build Amazon Machine Images (AMI's).

cluster.editAlert: This cluster cannot be edited as it was created using a different version of AWS ParallelCluster.

sshcommand.label: SSH command
sshcommand.tooltiptext: Copy the command to SSH into the head node. If the key pair you use to create the head node isn't the default, you must specify the path to the key pair. See <0>Connect to your Linux instance using an SSH Client</0> for more information.

ec2InstanceConnect.label: EC2 Instance Connect
ec2InstanceConnect.help: Locally install mSSH helper and copy the provided command to connect to the head node with EC2 Instance Connect.

storage.name: Name
storage.noFilesystemsToDisplay: Edit the cluster to add file systems.

filter.noFilesystems: No file systems match the filters.

costEstimate.title: Cost estimate
costEstimate.help: This cost estimate is based on the time taken for the job to run, the number of nodes, and an estimate of the node cost. The estimate could be inaccurate and is only meant to be an overall estimate.

empty.title: No jobs to display
empty.subtitle: From the cluster head node, submit a job and monitor its status.

scheduling.name: Name
scheduling.schedulingEnabled: Scheduling is only available in clusters with version 3.1.x and greater.
scheduling.ssmEnabled: You must enable SSM to monitor jobs.

empty.title: No jobs to display
empty.subtitle: From the cluster head node, submit a job and monitor its status.

logs.label: Select a log stream from the left.

help.main:
Create a new cluster or select a listed cluster to view detailed information.

Choose Create cluster to create and configure a cluster. Choose Step by step to create a cluster by using the widget only. Choose With a template if you want to choose a template to populate the wizard before you start. Choose With an existing cluster if you want to choose and existing cluster to populate the wizard before you start.

Choose Actions, Edit cluster to update the cluster configuration. Some configuration updates require that you first stop the compute fleet, and some updates can't be performed.

You can toggle Stop fleet | Start fleet to stop or start the cluster compute fleet. Choose Actions to Delete cluster.

You can only Create and Edit clusters with the same AWS ParallelCluster version that was used to create the AWS ParallelCluster UI.

Depending on the cluster configuration, you can use an AWS Systems Manager shell session or a DCV virtual desktop to access the head node of the selected cluster. From Actions, choose View file system to navigate to the cluster file system in the AWS management console, or choose View logs to view AWS ParallelCluster logs.

Enter text in the search field to find clusters by name, status, or version. Select a listed cluster to view its details.

<0>
help.details: Details shows a summary of cluster properties. To connect to the head node instance, use the link provided by the EC2 Instance Connect helper.
help.instances: Instances shows the list of cluster EC2 instances.
help.storage: Storage shows the list of your configured file systems.
help.accounting: Accounting shows a dashboard for your configured Slurm accounting data.
help.events: Stack events shows the record of cluster CloudFormation stack create, update, and delete events.

delete.title: Delete cluster
delete.body: Are you sure you want to delete cluster {{clusterName}}?

stop.title: Stop compute fleet
stop.body: Are you sure you want to stop compute fleet of cluster {{clusterName}}? This will terminate all jobs that are running and terminate any compute nodes running.

empty.title: No clusters to display
empty.subtitle: Click on Create cluster to create a cluster.

splitPanel.selectClusterText: Select a cluster to see its details

codeEditor.loadingError: There was an error loading the code editor.

fromClusterModal.title: Start with an existing cluster
fromClusterModal.description: Choose an existing cluster to populate the wizard before you start. You can only Create clusters with the same AWS ParallelCluster version that was used to create the AWS ParallelCluster UI.

helpPanel.title: $t(clusterLogs.title)
helpPanel.description:
View the AWS ParallelCluster logs that Amazon CloudWatch collects for your cluster.

You can also view these logs in the Amazon CloudWatch console and dashboard.

noMatch.title: No matches
noMatch.subtitle: No log stream matches the filters.

empty.title: No messages to display
empty.subtitle: Select a log stream to browse the messages.

activateButton.label: Activate cost monitoring
activateButton.activationSuccess: Cost monitoring activation might take up to 24 hours to complete. We are processing your request.

enableCostExplorerModal.title: Activating Cost Explorer
enableCostExplorerModal.description:
To use cost monitoring in the PCUI, open Cost Explorer in your account:

1. Log in to the AWS Management console and navigate to AWS Cost Management.
2. In the navigation pane, choose Cost Explorer.
3. In the Welcome page, choose Launch Cost Explorer.

empty.title: No spending data
empty.subtitle: No spending data to display. It might take 24 hours for data to be available.

cluster.title: Cluster
cluster.description: Configure the settings that apply to all cluster resources.

help.main:
Configure your cluster environment by selecting the AWS Region, operating system, and VPC.

Choose Multiple users on a cluster to use your Active Directory for managing multiple cluster users.

Choose Custom Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to use your custom AWS ParallelCluster image.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

validation.customAmiSelect: You must select an AMI ID if you add a custom AMI.

clusterName.label: Name
clusterName.description: The name must start with an alphabetical character and can have up to 60 characters. If Slurm accounting is configured, the name can have up to 40 characters. Valid characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and - (hyphen).
clusterName.cannotBeBlank: Cluster name must not be blank.
clusterName.alreadyExists: Cluster with name {{clusterName}} already exists. Choose a unique name.
clusterName.doesntMatchRegex: Cluster name '{{clusterName}}' doesn't match the the required format. Enter a name that starts with an alphabetical character and has up to 60 characters. If Slurm accounting is configured, the name can have up to 40 characters. Valid characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and - (hyphen)

region.label: Region
region.description: The AWS Region for the cluster.

os.label: Operating system
os.description: The operating system installed on the cluster nodes.

vpc.label: VPC
vpc.description: The VPC for the cluster instances.

imdsSupport.label: IMDS settings
imdsSupport.description: The IMDS version that cluster nodes use.

multiUser.title: Multiple user management properties
multiUser.description: Configure Active Directory access settings for multiple users on a cluster.
multiUser.help:
Configure access to your Active Directory by using LDAP.

Use your existing Active Directory or create one by using the quick create method described in the <0>$t(wizard.cluster.multiUser.adLink.title).

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

checkbox.label: Manage multiple users on a cluster

domainName.name: Domain name
domainName.description: The Active Directory (AD) domain that you use for identity information.
domainName.help: The Domain name corresponds to the SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_search_base.

domainAddress.name: Domain address
domainAddress.description: The URI or URIs that point to the Active Directory domain controller that's used as the LDAP server.
domainAddress.help: The URI corresponds to the SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_uri. The value can be a comma separated string of URIs. To use LDAP, you must add ldap:// to the beginning of the each URI.

passwordSecretArn.name: Password secret Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
passwordSecretArn.description: The ARN of the AWS Secrets Manager secret that contains the Domain Read Only User plaintext password.
passwordSecretArn.help: The content of the secret corresponds to the SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_default_authtok.

domainReadOnlyUser.name: Domain Read Only User
domainReadOnlyUser.description: The identity that's used to query the Active Directory domain for identity information when authenticating cluster user logins.
domainReadOnlyUser.help: The Domain Read Only User corresponds to SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_default_bind_dn. Use your Active Directory identity information for this value.

caCertificate.name: CA certificate
caCertificate.description: The absolute path to a certificates bundle containing the certificates for every CA in the certification chain that issued a certificate for the domain controllers.
caCertificate.help: The CA certificate corresponds to the SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_tls_cacert.

requireCertificate.name: Require certificate
requireCertificate.description: Specifies the checks to perform on server certificates in a TLS session.
requireCertificate.help: Require certificate corresponds to SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_tls_reqcert.

LDAPAccessFilter.name: LDAP access filter
LDAPAccessFilter.description: Specifies a filter to limit LDAP queries to a subset of the directory that's being queried.
LDAPAccessFilter.help: LDAP access filter corresponds to the SSSD-LDAP parameter that's called ldap_access_filter. You can use it to limit queries to an Active Directory that supports a large number of users.

generateSSHKeys.name: Generate SSH keys
generateSSHKeys.help:
Defines whether AWS ParallelCluster generates SSH key pairs for cluster users after they log in to the head node for the first time.

The key pair is saved to the user home directory at /home/username/.ssh/.

Users can use the SSH key pair for subsequent logins to the cluster head node and compute nodes.

With AWS ParallelCluster, logins to cluster compute nodes are disabled by design. If a user hasn't logged into the head node, SSH keys aren't generated and the user won't be able to log in to compute nodes.

sssdParameters.name: Additional SSSD Options
sssdParameters.description: Key-value pairs containing arbitrary SSSD parameters and values to write to the SSSD config file on cluster instances.
sssdParameters.validation: You must specify a value for both the key and value.

help.main:
Configure the head node of your cluster. The head node serves as the management node for cluster operations. You use the head node to access and manage the cluster and manage users. Cluster users access the head node to submit jobs.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

dcvLink.title: What is NICE DCV virtual desktop?

help.slurmSettings:
Configure Slurm accounting settings for your cluster.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

accountingLink.title: How Slurm accounting works with AWS ParallelCluster

validation.selectInstanceType: You must select an instance type.
validation.setRootVolumeSize: You must set a root volume size.
validation.rootVolumeMinimum: You must use an integer >= 35GB for root volume size.
validation.scriptWithArgs: You must specify a script path if you specify args.

Dcv.label: Virtual desktop
Dcv.help: Use the DCV virtual desktop to access the head node and visualize results. Increase your instance size if you add this option.

Ssm.title: SSM session
Ssm.label: Add SSM session
Ssm.help: You can access the head node by opening an SSM session when you choose the cluster from the list of clusters and select Shell. The required IAM policy is automatically added to the Additional IAM policies setting.

keypair.label: Key pair
keypair.description: Choose a key pair to connect to the head node by using SSH.

imdsSecured.label: IMDS
imdsSecured.help: IMDS secured restricts access to IMDS (and thus instance credentials) to users with superuser permissions.

imdsv2Link.title: How instance metadata service version 2 works

subnetId.label: Subnet ID
subnetId.description: Subnet ID for the head node.

securityGroups.label: Additional security groups
securityGroups.select: Select one or more security groups

validation.passwordCannotBeEmpty: Password secret ARN can't be empty
validation.scaledownIdleTimeLessThanOne: Scale down idle time is at least 1 minute

container.title: Slurm settings
container.description: Connect with an external Slurm database to monitor and analyze cluster usage.

database.label: Database
database.description: The path to the Slurm database.

username.label: Username
username.description: The user ID for access to the database.

password.label: Password secret ARN
password.description: The ARN of the AWS secret containing the database password.

scaledownIdleTime.label: Scale down idle time (in minutes)
scaledownIdleTime.description: The amount of time that a queue has no jobs before the Slurm node terminates.

queueUpdateStrategy.label: Queue update strategy
queueUpdateStrategy.description: Specifies the node replacement strategy for a queue.

storage.title: Storage
storage.description: Add and configure shared storage for your cluster. Shared storage is shared between the head node and compute nodes.

container.title: Storage settings
container.description: Add up to <0>20 file systems</0> for shared storage.

helpPanel.title: $t(wizard.storage.title)
helpPanel.description:
Add and configure shared storage for your cluster. Shared storage is shared between the head node and compute nodes.

Choose Add storage to configure shared storage for your cluster.

When you Edit shared storage configuration settings, AWS ParallelCluster doesn't check your inputs as you enter them. If your inputs can cause errors, AWS ParallelCluster returns validation error messages when you create the cluster or submit a dry run.

To see what settings can't be edited, search on the text "Update policy: If this setting is changed, the update is not allowed" in the Shared Storage section of the AWS ParallelCluster configuration documentation.

You can configure external or AWS ParallelCluster managed shared storage.

external.title: External storage
external.description: External storage refers to an existing volume or file system that you manage. AWS ParallelCluster doesn't create or delete external storage. You can configure AWS ParallelCluster to attach external storage to the cluster when the cluster is created or updated. Similarly, you can configure AWS ParallelCluster to detach external storage from the cluster when the cluster is deleted or edited. We recommend that you use external storage for long-term, permanent shared storage outside of the cluster lifecycle.

managed.title: AWS ParallelCluster managed storage
managed.description:
Managed storage refers to a volume or file system that AWS ParallelCluster creates and can delete. By default, AWS ParallelCluster managed storage is configured to depend on the lifecycle of the cluster. By default, an AWS ParallelCluster managed file system or volume and its data are deleted if you do one of the following things:

<0>

For EBS storage you can edit the Deletion Policy and change it from the default Delete to Retain. Then, if you delete the cluster, the EBS volume persists and can be used as external storage for another cluster. Deletion policy is set to Delete for all other managed shared storage types.

list.edit: Edit the configuration YAML to change the managed shared name.

recommendation.description:
We recommend that you regularly back up your data to avoid any data loss.

Learn more about shared storage properties, types, and quotas in Learn more.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

lustreType.label: FSx for Lustre
lustreType.help:
Choose SCRATCH_1 and SCRATCH_2 deployment types when you need temporary storage and shorter-term processing of data.

The SCRATCH_2 deployment type provides in-transit encryption of data and higher burst throughput capacity than SCRATCH_1.

Choose the PERSISTENT_2 deployment type for longer-term storage and workloads and encryption of data in transit.

Choose PERSISTENT_1 only for backwards compatibility.

import.label: Import path
import.help: Set Import path to read files into your file system from an S3 bucket. See <0>ImportPath</0>.

export.label: Export path
export.help: Set Export path to write files from your file system into an S3 bucket. See <0>ExportPath</0>.

throughput.label: Per unit storage throughput (MB/s/TiB)
throughput.help: Configure the amount of read and write throughput for each 1 tebibyte of storage, in MB/s/TiB.

compression.label: Compress file system data
compression.help: When data compression is used, Amazon FSx for Lustre automatically compresses newly written files before they are written to disk and automatically uncompresses them when they are read.

encrypted.label: Encrypted
encrypted.help: A custom AWS KMS key is used for encryption.

provisioned.label: Provisioned throughput (1-1024 in MiB/s)
provisioned.help: Configure the provisioned throughput (from 1-1024 in MiB/s) for the Amazon EFS file system. If not configured, the file system is created in bursting mode.

validation.provisionedThroughput: You must specify a valid provisioned throughput value.

encrypted.label: Encrypted
encrypted.help: A custom AWS KMS key is used for encryption.

snapshotId.label: Snapshot ID
snapshotId.help: Enter the Amazon EBS snapshot ID if you're using a snapshot as the source for the volume.

validation.volumeSize: You must specify a valid volume size.

mountPoint.label: Mount path
mountPoint.help: Configure the mount path for the shared storage on both the head node and compute nodes.

sourceName.label: Shared source name
sourceName.maxLengthError: Name can be at most {{maxChars}} characters
sourceName.forbiddenCharsError: The name contains one or more forbidden characters
sourceName.forbiddenKeywordError: The name contains a forbidden keyword

useExisting.label: External file system
useExisting.error: You must specify an external file system ID.
useExisting.help: Specify an external file system and mount it to all instances in the cluster.

deletionPolicy.label: Deletion policy
deletionPolicy.help: Configure whether the volume should be retained, deleted, or snapshotted when a cluster is deleted.

description.newResourcesLimits: Configure up to {{limit}} queues, with a total of {{maxCRPerCluster}} compute resources for each cluster.

help.main:
Configure your cluster queues for job scheduling.

Add and remove queues and queue compute resources.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

validation.maxLengthName: Name can be at most {{maxChars}} characters
validation.forbiddenCharsName: Name must start with a lowercase letter and can only contain lowercase letters, numbers and hyphens
validation.instanceTypeUnique: Instance types must be unique within a queue.
validation.instanceTypeMissing: Select at least one instance type.
validation.selectSubnets: You must select at least one subnet.
validation.setRootVolumeSize: You must set a root volume size.
validation.rootVolumeMinimum: You must use an integer >= 35GB for root volume size.
validation.scriptWithArgs: You must specify a script path if you specify args.
validation.customAmiSelect: You must select an AMI ID if you use a custom AMI.

container.title: Slurm settings
container.help:
Use Slurm memory-based scheduling to specify the amount of memory per node required by a job with Slurm's --mem parameter.

Choose a queue update strategy.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

memorySchedulingLink.title: How Slurm memory-based scheduling works with AWS ParallelCluster

info.header: You can use Slurm memory based scheduling only when you select one instance type
info.body: If you select more than one instance type in any queue, Slurm memory-based scheduling isn't available by default.

helpPanel.title: Allocation strategy
helpPanel.description: Choose the strategy for allocating instances to compute resources.

schedulableMemory.name: Schedulable memory (in MiB)
schedulableMemory.description: The amount of memory (in MiB) made available to jobs on the compute nodes of the compute resource
schedulableMemory.help: The default value is 95 percent of the memory advertised by EC2.

placeholder.multiple: Select one or more instance types

helpPanel.title: $t(wizard.queues.computeResource.disableHT.label)
helpPanel.description: Prevent multiple threads from running on an EC2 instance core.

helpPanel.title: Purchase type
helpPanel.description: Choose the instance purchasing type for compute resources.

create.title: Create
create.description: Review or edit your cluster configuration and create your cluster.
create.pending: {{clusterName}} create is in progress. In Clusters, view {{clusterName}} create status.

configuration.title: Cluster configuration YAML file
configuration.description: Review or edit the YAML file that is used to create your cluster.
configuration.forceUpdate: Force update: Edit the cluster while the compute fleet is still running.

helpPanel.title: Cluster configuration
helpPanel.description:
Review, edit and test cluster configuration.

Choose Dry run to validate your configuration without creating your cluster.

Choose Create to validate your configuration and create your cluster in one step.

update.title: Edit
update.pending: {{clusterName}} update is in progress. In Clusters, view {{clusterName}} update status.

helpPanel.title: Cluster configuration
helpPanel.description:
Review, edit and test cluster configuration.

Choose Dry run to validate your configuration without editing your cluster.

Choose Edit cluster to validate your configuration and edit your cluster in one step.

customAmi.ariaLabel: Use a custom Amazon Machine Image (AMI)
customAmi.label: Use a custom Amazon Machine Image (AMI)

helpPanel.title: Custom Amazon Machine Image (AMI)
helpPanel.description: Use a custom Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to customize your cluster.

header.title: Users
header.description: The list of users that have permission to access the AWS ParallelCluster UI.

helpPanel.title: Users
helpPanel.description:
Maintain the list of cognito users with credentials that only permit access to the $t(global.projectName).

Enter a user email address and choose Add user

Choose Remove to remove a user.

Choose Refresh to view changes to the list of users.

errors.invalidEmail: You must enter a valid email

delete.title: Delete user
delete.body: Are you sure you want to delete user {{userEmail}}?

header.title: Custom images
header.description: The list of custom images that you created. Custom images are customized AMIs that are used to build a <0>customized AWS ParallelCluster</0>.

helpPanel.title: Custom images
helpPanel.description:
Choose Build image to create your custom image.

You can only build images with the same AWS ParallelCluster version that was used to create the $t(global.projectName).

If you choose Build image, you proceed to create a custom image by uploading a configuration, by entering the ID of an existing image, or by manually entering the configuration.

After you have provided the configuration, you choose Build image.

Choose Refresh to view recently changed or added AWS resources.

empty.title: No images to display
empty.subtitle: Click on Build image to create an image.

splitPanel.selectImageText: Select an image to see its details

empty.title: No tags to display
empty.subtitle: Use the Tags property of the image configuration to add tags to the image.

configurationUrl.label: Configuration URL
configurationUrl.tooltiptext: Image configuration URL copied to clipboard.

buildImage.title: Image configuration
buildImage.imageIdError: Image ID must not be blank

header.title: Official images
header.description: The official list of tested Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) that are automatically used to create AWS ParallelClusters.

helpPanel.title: Official images
helpPanel.description:
Refer to this list of AMI images when configuring your cluster.

This version-coupled instance of the $t(global.projectName) automatically uses these tested AMIs to create clusters based on the operating system and architecture that you choose.

ClusterFailedHelp.errorMessage: Stack failed to create, see <0>CloudFormation stack events</0> or <1>Cluster logs</1> to see why.
